brand.name: Halifax
brand.description: Halifax is one of Britain’s most well-known brands. It is now part of Lloyds Banking Group, following the merger between Lloyds TSB and HBOS in 2009. It is probably best known as one of the country’s largest mortgage and savings providers but Halifax also offers a range of credit cards.

eligibilityCriteria.type: Must be aged 18 or over
Must be a UK resident
Must have a regular income
Must not be currently declared bankrupt, have any County Court Judgments against you or be subject to an Individual Voluntary Arrangement

repaymentDetails.allocationOfPaymentsDescription: Halifax use your payments to pay off balances charged at the highest interest rate first and so on down to balances with the lowest interest rates. This means the more expensive balances are always paid off first. If there is more than one type of balance at the same interest rate, they are paid off in the following order: cash transactions, purchases, balance transfers and money transfers, and then default charges (plus any interest or charges incurred as a result of those balances). For each type of balance, your payments will pay off the oldest balance (and related fees, charges or insurance) first

brand.name: MBNA
brand.description: MBNA has been issuing credit cards in the UK for over 20 years, giving them a wealth of experience. Their customers voted them Credit Card Provider of the Year at the Consumer Moneyfacts Awards in 2014, 2015 and 2016. Working with a number of partners, MBNA aims to offer benefits, flexibility and choice across a variety of credit card types. With an emphasis on security, innovations such as contactless and mobile payments, and smart ways to manage your account (including an app), MBNA continues to cater for a wide range of customer needs.

eligibilityCriteria.type: Must be aged 18 or over
Must have been a permanent UK resident for three years or more
Must have a UK bank or building society account
Must have a good credit rating/history

repaymentDetails.allocationOfPaymentsDescription:
MBNA allocate your payment to amounts that are charged at higher interest rates before those that are charged at lower interest rates.

• If MBNA charge interest at the same rate on different parts of your balance, they will allocate your payment to the introductory rate first.
• If two or more introductory rates are the same MBNA will pay off the introductory rate with the earliest start date first.
• If the introductory rates have the same start date then MBNA will pay off that part which will be charged at the highest standard rate at the end of the introductory period.
• MBNA will then apply your payment to balance transfers, cash advances, money transfers and purchases, in that order.

repaymentDetails.allocationOfPaymentsDescription: Payments received will be applied to the different amounts of your outstanding balance in the order of highest interest rate to lowest interest rate. eligibilityCriteria.type: Must have an annual income of £5,000 or more
Must be aged 18 or over
Must have a good credit history
Must live in the UK or have a BFPO address

repaymentDetails.allocationOfPaymentsDescription:
When you pay Tesco Bank, they use it to pay off:
  • First those items which attract the highest interest rates.
  • This will normally be in the order of interest and fees followed by transaction type of cash advances, standard rate balance transfers, purchases and money transfers, special offer rates.
  • If there is more than one item at the same rate Tesco Bank pay off the item at the rate that ends first.
  • If your account is in arrears, Tesco Bank will pay off the arrears on your account (starting with the oldest) before they put it towards the amount due from your most recent statement.
  • If you have Buy Now Pay Later special offer items, Tesco Bank will pay these off after they have paid off everything else on your statement.

results.name: Platinum Credit Card

brand.name: MBNA
brand.description: MBNA has been issuing credit cards in the UK for over 20 years, giving them a wealth of experience. Their customers voted them Credit Card Provider of the Year at the Consumer Moneyfacts Awards in 2014, 2015 and 2016. Working with a number of partners, MBNA aims to offer benefits, flexibility and choice across a variety of credit card types. With an emphasis on security, innovations such as contactless and mobile payments, and smart ways to manage your account (including an app), MBNA continues to cater for a wide range of customer needs.

eligibilityCriteria.type: Must be aged 18 years or over
Must have been a permanent UK resident for three years or more
Must have a UK bank or building society account
Must have a good credit rating/history

repaymentDetails.allocationOfPaymentsDescription:
MBNA allocate your payment to amounts that are charged at higher interest rates before those that are charged at lower interest rates.

• If MBNA charge interest at the same rate on different parts of your balance, they will allocate your payment to the introductory rate first.
• If two or more introductory rates are the same MBNA will pay off the introductory rate with the earliest start date first.
• If the introductory rates have the same start date then MBNA will pay off that part which will be charged at the highest standard rate at the end of the introductory period.
• MBNA will then apply your payment to balance transfers, cash advances, money transfers and purchases, in that order.

results.name: Clubcard Credit Card for Balance Transfers

positiveFeatures.name: Earn Clubcard points wherever you use your card, on top of your usual Clubcard points in Tesco
You're eligible to apply for this card even if you've already got another Tesco Bank credit card

negativeFeatures.name: You might get a different interest rate to the one shown here, because this depends on your circumstances
You must transfer a balance within the first 90 days to get the promotional offer. 0% interest rates apply from the day you open your account
You're not eligible if you've applied for another Tesco Bank credit card in the last month

brand.name: Tesco Bank
brand.description: Tesco Bank pride themselves on their range of simple and convenient retail banking and insurance products designed specifically to meet the needs of Tesco customers.

eligibilityCriteria.type: Must have an annual income of £5,000 or more
Must be 18 years of age or over (the same goes for any additional card holders)
Must have a good credit history
Must live in the UK or have a BFPO address

repaymentDetails.allocationOfPaymentsDescription:
When you make a payment, Tesco will use it to pay off:
  • First those items which attract the highest interest rates.
  • This will normally be in the order of interest and fees followed by transaction type of cash advances, standard rate balance transfers, purchases and money transfers, special offer rates.
  • If there is more than one item at the same rate Tesco pay off the item at the rate that ends first.
  • If your account is in arrears, Tesco will pay off the arrears on your account (starting with the oldest) before they put it towards the amount due from your most recent statement.
  • If you have Buy Now Pay Later special offer items, Tesco will pay these off after they have paid off everything else on your statement.

brand.name: Halifax
brand.description: Halifax is one of Britain’s most well-known brands. It is now part of Lloyds Banking Group, following the merger between Lloyds TSB and HBOS in 2009. It is probably best known as one of the country’s largest mortgage and savings providers but Halifax also offers a range of credit cards.

eligibilityCriteria.type: Must be aged 18 or over
Must be a UK resident
Must have a regular income
Must not be currently declared bankrupt, have any County Court Judgments against you or be subject to an Individual Voluntary Arrangement

repaymentDetails.allocationOfPaymentsDescription: Halifax use your payments to pay off balances charged at the highest interest rate first and so on down to balances with the lowest interest rates. This means the more expensive balances are always paid off first. If there is more than one type of balance at the same interest rate, they are paid off in the following order: cash transactions, purchases, balance transfers and money transfers, and then default charges (plus any interest or charges incurred as a result of those balances). For each type of balance, your payments will pay off the oldest balance (and related fees, charges or insurance) first
